newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINNISH BONDS QUIETLY STEADY, EYE FRENCH ELECTIONS.
newsitem.headline: FINNISH BONDS QUIETLY STEADY, EYE FRENCH ELECTIONS.

text.p: Bonds were steady in quiet trade on Friday afternoon after tracking German Bunds lower in early dealings ahead of a U.S. holiday on Monday, dealers said.
Uncertainty ahead of the first round of the French elections this weekend made operators wary; a ruling centre-right victory was partly priced in, they said.
"A socialist victory could lead towards a weaker Euro, and that would send yields higher," one dealer said.
Merita analyst Jukka Lepomaki said it seemed a majority was expecting a conservative win, but there could still be a positive reaction in Germany, and Finland would follow.
"But the spread over Germany is really tight now," he added.
The 2006 bond yield gap over the 2007 Bund was stuck at 29
France has insisted that countries wishing to join EMU
should stick to a Maastricht treaty criterion limiting budget
deficits to three percent of gross domestic product (GDP) this
year but the opposition Socialists have argued for a flexible
The forex market was also calm, dealers said, with the
markka moving between 3.01 and 3.02 per mark.
